title: Starting School With Food Allergies

content: One of the top questions I am asked repeatedly is how to safely send a child with food allergies to school, particularly those first years of preschool and kindergarten. My boys are now in middle school, and in hindsight, I can tell you with certainty that those early school years were the hardest to manage.

At that age, children are still putting everything in their mouths. Kids are really too young to fully understand their food allergies or advocate for themselves. And the mess! It is age-appropriate for youngsters to eat and play while leaving a path of destruction behind them. This is all fine, unless, of course, the mess includes your child’s food allergen.

Thankfully, I’m far on the other side now. That said, I still clearly remember my fear, stress, and worry during those years. A big part of the problem was that I didn’t know what to request of the school in order to make the classroom as safe as possible for my boys. How could I, as a first-time preschool parent and first-time food allergy parent? However, I have learned so many important lessons. I’m happy to share my top three tips with you about how to safely get your child with food allergies through the first school years.

content_blocks.text: One of the top questions I am asked repeatedly is how to safely send a child with food allergies to school, particularly those first years of preschool and kindergarten. My boys are now in middle school, and in hindsight, I can tell you with certainty that those early school years were the hardest to manage.

At that age, children are still putting everything in their mouths. Kids are really too young to fully understand their food allergies or advocate for themselves. And the mess! It is age-appropriate for youngsters to eat and play while leaving a path of destruction behind them. This is all fine, unless, of course, the mess includes your child’s food allergen.

Thankfully, I’m far on the other side now. That said, I still clearly remember my fear, stress, and worry during those years. A big part of the problem was that I didn’t know what to request of the school in order to make the classroom as safe as possible for my boys. How could I, as a first-time preschool parent and first-time food allergy parent? However, I have learned so many important lessons. I’m happy to share my top three tips with you about how to safely get your child with food allergies through the first school years.

sections.heading: A Trip Down Memory Lane
content: But first, let me take you down memory lane so you can understand how I learned enough to give this advice to you. Hint: The hard way! My oldest son began preschool in a nearby church program. It’s a darling local church, and everyone in the neighborhood sends their kids to this school. He had not even been diagnosed with food allergies as he began his 3-year-old program, so none of this was on my radar. Halfway through the year, he had his first bite of peanut butter, followed by his first allergic reaction, followed by a diagnosis of allergies to peanuts and all tree nuts. We were stunned.

One saving grace was that a sweet little girl in his class also had a peanut allergy, and her mom quickly became my best friend. The teacher was (fairly) competent in managing nut allergy, but she commented several times about how the little girl did a better job “advocating for herself” than my son. Who was 3. And who had literally just been diagnosed.

content_blocks.text: But first, let me take you down memory lane so you can understand how I learned enough to give this advice to you. Hint: The hard way! My oldest son began preschool in a nearby church program. It’s a darling local church, and everyone in the neighborhood sends their kids to this school. He had not even been diagnosed with food allergies as he began his 3-year-old program, so none of this was on my radar. Halfway through the year, he had his first bite of peanut butter, followed by his first allergic reaction, followed by a diagnosis of allergies to peanuts and all tree nuts. We were stunned.

One saving grace was that a sweet little girl in his class also had a peanut allergy, and her mom quickly became my best friend. The teacher was (fairly) competent in managing nut allergy, but she commented several times about how the little girl did a better job “advocating for herself” than my son. Who was 3. And who had literally just been diagnosed.

content: I scheduled a meeting with the head of the preschool to learn more about their food allergy policies. She told me that the school would not be nut-free, but the classroom would be nut-free if a child in the room had an allergy. However, when I walked down the hallway of the school, I noticed that literally every single classroom had a note on the door that said that classroom was nut-free due to an allergy. Yet, the school still served peanut butter and jelly sandwiches at events. And then a teacher sat down next to my son on a field trip with a peanut butter sandwich. A teacher! Thank goodness I was also on the field trip and asked her politely to move.

My final straw with that school was when I met with the director yet again to discuss the repeated peanut butter incidents, and she responded by saying her job was to teach my son to advocate for himself. Again, he was 3 years old. I told her that MY job was to teach him to advocate for himself when it was age appropriate. HER job was to create a safe and inclusive environment for him to learn.

content_blocks.text: I scheduled a meeting with the head of the preschool to learn more about their food allergy policies. She told me that the school would not be nut-free, but the classroom would be nut-free if a child in the room had an allergy. However, when I walked down the hallway of the school, I noticed that literally every single classroom had a note on the door that said that classroom was nut-free due to an allergy. Yet, the school still served peanut butter and jelly sandwiches at events. And then a teacher sat down next to my son on a field trip with a peanut butter sandwich. A teacher! Thank goodness I was also on the field trip and asked her politely to move.

My final straw with that school was when I met with the director yet again to discuss the repeated peanut butter incidents, and she responded by saying her job was to teach my son to advocate for himself. Again, he was 3 years old. I told her that MY job was to teach him to advocate for himself when it was age appropriate. HER job was to create a safe and inclusive environment for him to learn.

content: We left the school.

Fast-forward, and we found another wonderful church nursery school with a director who totally “got it.” She was a food allergy mom herself and helped me navigate those early years. By this time, my younger son had also had his first anaphylactic reaction, to his first bite of banana, and then was diagnosed with allergies to wheat, dairy, egg, peanut, tree nuts, and more. The stakes were suddenly even higher as our list of allergens grew.

Later, when we tried to schedule a meeting with the principal of our local public elementary school for kindergarten, we were told he would not meet with us unless we were already enrolled. I responded that we couldn’t enroll if we didn’t understand their food allergy policies. They directed me to the school nurse, who told me the epinephrine stays locked in her office; she is not always there to unlock it if needed; my son would have to sit at an allergy table at lunch; they couldn’t guarantee that he would not be sitting alone at lunch; and that if we didn’t like that, we should look at private school.

content_blocks.text: We left the school.

Fast-forward, and we found another wonderful church nursery school with a director who totally “got it.” She was a food allergy mom herself and helped me navigate those early years. By this time, my younger son had also had his first anaphylactic reaction, to his first bite of banana, and then was diagnosed with allergies to wheat, dairy, egg, peanut, tree nuts, and more. The stakes were suddenly even higher as our list of allergens grew.

Later, when we tried to schedule a meeting with the principal of our local public elementary school for kindergarten, we were told he would not meet with us unless we were already enrolled. I responded that we couldn’t enroll if we didn’t understand their food allergy policies. They directed me to the school nurse, who told me the epinephrine stays locked in her office; she is not always there to unlock it if needed; my son would have to sit at an allergy table at lunch; they couldn’t guarantee that he would not be sitting alone at lunch; and that if we didn’t like that, we should look at private school.

content: Hard pass.
My husband and I had many lengthy discussions about this feedback. Should we fight the system? Is it even legal to say that to us? Do we go in and enforce change? Or do we look at our other options?

Personally, I was already frazzled from seeing a few terrifying anaphylactic reactions, managing multiple allergist appointments, and working through two different preschools. We had the wonderful opportunity to apply to two private schools, and the boys got into both. We tried them each for a year, learned many lessons, and chose the one that handled food allergies better. Our boys still attend that school to this day and (knock on wood!) have never had any food allergy incident or reaction. Thank goodness.
My Top 3 Tips

While I know private school may not be an option everyone wants or has, I can tell you without question that it’s important to know what options you DO have as you navigate those early years. After two boys and four schools, I’ve got you covered. Here are the three tips to consider when entering the early school years with your food-allergic kiddo.

content_blocks.text: Hard pass.

Personally, I was already frazzled from seeing a few terrifying anaphylactic reactions, managing multiple allergist appointments, and working through two different preschools. We had the wonderful opportunity to apply to two private schools, and the boys got into both. We tried them each for a year, learned many lessons, and chose the one that handled food allergies better. Our boys still attend that school to this day and (knock on wood!) have never had any food allergy incident or reaction. Thank goodness.
My Top 3 Tips

While I know private school may not be an option everyone wants or has, I can tell you without question that it’s important to know what options you DO have as you navigate those early years. After two boys and four schools, I’ve got you covered. Here are the three tips to consider when entering the early school years with your food-allergic kiddo.

sections.heading: Tip 1. Research Your Options
content: There are so many preschool options available these days, and they are not all created equal. If you are considering an early education program for your child, research the landscape in your town. Look at the websites for the schools, talk to other parents, ask your pediatrician and allergist for their insights, and set up appointments to meet with the administration. Keep in mind that my boys were in preschool over 10 years ago, and the food allergy world has expanded exponentially. My hope is that you will find many more schools that are well-versed in food allergy management.

My advice for you: If at all possible, don’t pick the school where you have the steepest climb in understanding. Food allergy life is hard enough without having to start from scratch with education. Focus on the schools that already have at least a basic understanding of food allergies, including good policies in place to keep students safe and included.

content_blocks.text: There are so many preschool options available these days, and they are not all created equal. If you are considering an early education program for your child, research the landscape in your town. Look at the websites for the schools, talk to other parents, ask your pediatrician and allergist for their insights, and set up appointments to meet with the administration. Keep in mind that my boys were in preschool over 10 years ago, and the food allergy world has expanded exponentially. My hope is that you will find many more schools that are well-versed in food allergy management.

My advice for you: If at all possible, don’t pick the school where you have the steepest climb in understanding. Food allergy life is hard enough without having to start from scratch with education. Focus on the schools that already have at least a basic understanding of food allergies, including good policies in place to keep students safe and included.

sections.heading: Tip 2.  Ask for Accommodations
content: These are the questions I get most often in my social media direct messages: What do I ask of a teacher or school to keep my kid safe? What is fair? What if they say no?

First, note that the rules you might need in place in preschool and kindergarten will not be what you’ll need forever. It’s crucial to understand that these first few years can be more stressful because of how young the kids are, but it is still possible to ask for accommodations to keep them safe. After a bumpy start, and some learning by trial and error, here’s what we ultimately asked for in the later parts of our boys’ preschool-through-kindergarten years:
bullets: Both our preschool and elementary school were nut-aware schools, so we didn’t have to ask for their classrooms to be nut free. Keep in mind that it’s never going to be perfect, but at least one battle had already been fought for us.

Our biggest learning was to ask for no food IN the classroom. It’s impossible to get 3- to 5-year-olds to eat without getting food everywhere. When there was any type of food in the classroom, our youngest son was in constant reaction mode. Simply request that the class move to the cafeteria or another space outside of the classroom to eat snacks and lunch. This allows the classroom to remain an allergen-free zone and keeps teachers from having to constantly clean up. Remind the teachers that many art supplies have food ingredients (for example, Play-Doh contains wheat), and request that they read all labels before bringing new products into the classroom.

If your child has a potentially life-threatening allergy, request that the class not have that food at all. For example, our youngest son had a terrifying, nearly fatal reaction to bananas as an infant, and we requested that his class not allow bananas from preschool through elementary school. (Side note, to give you a glimpse of the light at the end of the tunnel, he passed bananas in an oral food challenge in middle school.) I did not ask for ALL of his allergens to be removed from the class because that would have been nearly impossible for the school and other parents to manage.

Finally, we asked that all children be required to wash their hands after eating, or at a minimum, use hand wipes to remove allergens. I also offered to help supply hand wipes for the classroom, from preschool all the way through elementary school.

sections.heading: Tip 3. Educate to Advocate
content: When you are a food allergy parent, you become a food allergy advocate immediately upon that diagnosis, whether you realize it or not. This might feel overwhelming at first, but it is truly such an opportunity to make life better for your child and pay it forward for the families who will come after you. Head into those early years of school with an intention of teamwork with the teachers and administration, rather than a stance of fearful demands. Understand that you can bring your list of requested accommodations, and they may not be able to promise them all. However, be open to negotiating ways they CAN offer protections for your child. Your teacher might even have ideas for you after their own experiences.
Here are the best ways I found to communicate with teachers:
bullets: Introduce yourself to the teacher before school starts — the earlier, the better. Copy the school nurse, if you have one, and the preschool director or principal. Tell them about your child and their food allergies, and tell them you’d like to work together to make this a successful, safe, and inclusive year for all. Request a meeting before school starts to make a plan.

Bring a complete emergency action plan that includes your child’s allergies and reaction treatment scenarios. You can find a template for this on the Food Allergy Research and Education (FARE) website. Make sure to discuss this with your allergist and get their signature prior to your meeting.

Create a one-page document with your suggested accommodations for your child. Try to really focus on what is most important and not create extra work for the teacher whenever possible. If you are able, financially or timewise, offer to help supply snacks, art supplies, wipes, or hand soap. You can also offer to attend field trips or any school event where food might be present, so that you’ll be the one responsible for watching over your child.

Provide a short but verified list of resources for the teacher and administration to review before school starts to ensure they are educated on food allergy basics. Include information on how to recognize signs of anaphylaxis and how to give epinephrine. Again, the FARE website is an excellent resource for this and even has training modules for teachers and school nurses. Food Allergy & Anaphylaxis Connection Team (FAACT) is another tremendous resource for education materials for you, your teachers, and your school. They have an in-depth accommodations section on their website if you’d like more ideas about what to request for your child. Lastly, another great resource to share is the Snack Safely Guide online, which has verified lists of packaged goods that are free from top allergens.
Take your epinephrine training device to your meeting and show your teacher how to use it.

Provide your email address and cell phone number and tell teachers to text, call, or email any time they have a question. I have gotten hundreds of texts over the years with product labels or last-minute questions from our teachers. Their willingness to openly communicate with you will create comfort for everyone.

content: It’s important to research 504 plans before you have your meeting with your school. Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 prohibits institutions (such as schools) that receive federal funding to discriminate against a child based on disability, including food allergies. A 504 plan will not be an option in a private preschool or school, but is incredibly helpful in a public school. We never had one, so I can’t provide details, but both FARE and FAACT have extremely helpful information should you need one to receive the accommodations you deserve for your child.

Phew! That’s a lot of information and to-dos for you, but I do hope this roadmap will help you feel empowered to advocate for your child. When I look back now, I was so stressed and overwhelmed because I didn’t know what to ask for or how to manage the classroom setting. I had to learn by trial and error and by switching schools — a few times! I hope your road is much less bumpy and that this helps you navigate those early years more easily.

We never had one, so I can’t provide details, but both FARE and FAACT have extremely helpful information should you need one to receive the accommodations you deserve for your child.

content: Fast-forward to today and my boys are both in middle school, as I mentioned at the beginning, and they have not had a single food allergy reaction in nine years of school. (I’m knocking wood again right now!) Their school continues to be nut-aware, and we have slowly lifted accommodations over the years, both based on testing out of allergies and treatment with oral immunotherapy.

As they’ve gotten older, they’ve also been able to learn to advocate for themselves appropriately. We no longer exclude any allergens from their classrooms. My older son is able to eat from the school cafeteria, and my younger son still brings lunch along with hand wipes that he uses to wipe the table and his hands before eating. And, thanks to years of practice, they have the confidence to speak up if there are any surprise situations with their allergens present. I am so proud of them. I am so proud of us!

content_blocks.text: Fast-forward to today and my boys are both in middle school, as I mentioned at the beginning, and they have not had a single food allergy reaction in nine years of school. (I’m knocking wood again right now!) As they’ve gotten older, they’ve also been able to learn to advocate for themselves appropriately. We no longer exclude any allergens from their classrooms. My older son is able to eat from the school cafeteria, and my younger son still brings lunch along with hand wipes that he uses to wipe the table and his hands before eating. And, thanks to years of practice, they have the confidence to speak up if there are any surprise situations with their allergens present. I am so proud of them. I am so proud of us!

content: Take heart. It really does get so much easier. You will all learn so much in those early years. But remember, you need to find a school that can be your partner to keep your little ones safe and included as they learn. Once you find the right school, create an open dialogue with their teacher and ask for accommodations. And lastly, advocate for your child by educating the teachers about food allergies. Because despite my first preschool director’s stance, 3-year-olds are not responsible for advocating for themselves.
I wish you the best of luck. You’ve got this!
Photo Credit: svetikd / Getty Images
